sp.p:
knowledge of natural history, who will
measure imaginative work by their own
lack of any imaginative faculty, and
will hold up their inkstained hands
in horror if some honest gentleman, who
has never been farther than the yew-
trees of his own garden, pens a
fascinating book of travels in strange lands, like Sir
John Mandeville,85 or, like great Raleigh,
writes a whole Hhistory of the Wworld,
in prison, without knowinganything
whatsoever about the subject past. To excuse themselves
they will try and shelter under the
shield of him who made Prospero
the magician, and gave him Caliban
and Ariel to serve him as his servants, who
heard the Tritons blowing their horns
round the coral reefs of the Enchanted [???]
Isle,,86 and the fairies singing to each
other in a wood near Athens, who
led the phantom Kkings in dim procession
across the misty Scottish heath, and
hid Hecate in a cave with the weird
sisters. They will call upon Shakespeare--
they always do--and will quote that
hackneyed passage about Art holding
the mirror up to Nature,87 forgetting that
this unfortunate aphorism is deliberately
said by Hamlet in order to convince
the bystanders of his absolute
insanity in all art matters.'"

C.Cyril.yril. Ahem! Ahem! Aanother cigarette,
please.
